thread.title: Gigi and Bella Hadid join NYC demonstrators in #NoBanNoWall march
thread.title_full: Gigi and Bella Hadid join NYC demonstrators in #NoBanNoWall march

author: USA TODAY
title: Gigi and Bella Hadid join NYC demonstrators in #NoBanNoWall march
text:
Let friends in your social network know what you are reading about Facebook Email Gigi and Bella Hadid join NYC demonstrators in #NoBanNoWall march The supermodels used their platform to pose a challenge to Trump's executive orders. Post to Facebook Gigi and Bella Hadid join NYC demonstrators in #NoBanNoWall march The supermodels used their platform to pose a challenge to Trump's executive orders. Check out this story on USATODAY.com: http://usat.ly/2jNvHLT Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Nation's Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Gigi and Bella Hadid join NYC demonstrators in #NoBanNoWall march Jaleesa M. Jones , USA TODAY Published 10:06 a.m. ET Jan. 30, 2017 | Updated 7 hours ago Gigi Hadid, left, and Bella Hadid attend the Global Lyme Alliance "Uniting for a Lyme-Free World" Inaugural Gala at Cipriani 42nd Street on Oct. 8, 2015 in New York City. (Photo: Dimitrios Kambouris, Getty Images) 
They’re the fashion industry’s "It Girls," and on Sunday, supermodels Gigi and Bella Hadid used their platform to pose a challenge to President Donald Trump's polarizing anti-immigration orders. 
Joining New York City demonstrators , the Hadid sisters participated in the #NoBanNoWall march, carrying a sign emblazoned with a heart and the unifying message, "We are all H indus, B u ddhists, M uslims, A theists, Christia n s, Jew s ," with specific letters bolded to spell out the word "Humans." A photo posted by Bella Hadid (@bellahadid) on Jan 29, 2017 at 8:56pm PST 
The supermodels also chanted in protest of the executive order , which temporarily bans immigration and the entry of refugees into the U.S. by citizens from seven Muslim-majority countries: Iran, Sudan, Syria, Iraq, Libya, Somalia and Yemen. 
The move struck a personal chord with the Hadid sisters whose parents are both immigrants. Their mother, former model and Real Housewives of Beverly Hills star Yolanda Hadid, hails from the Netherlands while their father, property mogul Mohamed Hadid, is Palestinian and of Muslim faith. Gigi’s boyfriend, Mind of Mine artist Zayn Malik, is also Muslim. 
Federal Judge Ann Donnelly in Brooklyn issued an emergency stay on Trump's order late Saturday. The stay in proceedings covers those have already arrived in the U.S. and valid visa holders who are en route, but celebrities like the Hadids are continuing to push for the executive orders to be overturned completely. 
See images from their protest below. Gigi Hadid at the #NoBanNoWall march in New York, January 29th. pic.twitter.com/CaT2IdHEV0 — Gigi Hadid News (@GigiHadidsNews) January 30, 2017 Gigi and Bella Hadid at the #NoBanNoWall march in New York, January 29th. pic.twitter.com/DwYV04sFCh
